SEARCH
Package com.github.tommyettinger.digital

Interface Interpolations.InterpolationFunction

All Known Implementing Classes:
Interpolations.Interpolator
Enclosing class:
Interpolations
public static interface Interpolations.InterpolationFunction
A type of function that takes a float from 0 to 1 (usually, and also usually inclusive) and returns a float that is typically in the 0 to 1 range or just outside it. Meant for easier communication with libGDX's Interpolation class by using one of its Interpolation constants with a method reference. This is a functional interface whose functional method is apply(float).

  • Method Summary

    Modifier and Type
    Method
    Description
    float
    apply(float alpha)
    Given a float alpha, which is almost always between 0 and 1 inclusive, gets a typically-different float that is usually (but not always) between 0 and 1 inclusive.
    default float
    apply(float start, float end, float alpha)
    Maps a call to apply(float) from the 0-1 range to the start-end range.
    default Interpolations.InterpolationFunction
    flip()
    Effectively splits the interpolation function at its midway point (where alpha is 0.5) and returns a new InterpolationFunction that interpolates like the first half when alpha is greater than 0.5, and interpolates like the second half when alpha is less than 0.5.

  • Method Details

    • apply

      float apply(float alpha)
      Given a float alpha, which is almost always between 0 and 1 inclusive, gets a typically-different float that is usually (but not always) between 0 and 1 inclusive.
      Parameters:
      alpha - almost always between 0 and 1, inclusive
      Returns:
      a value that is usually between 0 and 1, inclusive, for inputs between 0 and 1

    • apply

      default float apply(float start, float end, float alpha)
      Maps a call to apply(float) from the 0-1 range to the start-end range. Usually (but not always), this returns a float between start and end, inclusive.
      Parameters:
      start - the inclusive lower bound; some functions can return less
      end - the inclusive upper bound; some functions can return more
      alpha - almost always between 0 and 1, inclusive
      Returns:
      a value that is usually between start and end, inclusive, for alpha between 0 and 1

    • flip

      default Interpolations.InterpolationFunction flip()
      Effectively splits the interpolation function at its midway point (where alpha is 0.5) and returns a new InterpolationFunction that interpolates like the first half when alpha is greater than 0.5, and interpolates like the second half when alpha is less than 0.5. In both cases, the returned function will be offset so that it starts at 0 when alpha is 0, ends at 1 when alpha is 1, and returns 0.5 when alpha is 0.5, but only so long as this original InterpolationFunction also has those behaviors. If this InterpolationFunction does not return 0 at 0, 1 at 1, and 0.5 at 0.5, then the InterpolationFunction this returns may not be continuous.
      This is meant to create variants on "In, Out" interpolation functions that instead go "Out, In."
      Returns:
      a new InterpolationFunction that acts like this one, but with its starting and ending halves switched
